name: All the Broken Places: A Novel

title: The best book!!
content: This was the best book I’ve read in a long time. It is so well written. I loved ALL of the characters and how the author intertwined them all. Historical fiction fans- This is a must read.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on October 6, 2024

title: Verified Purchase
content: I love historical fiction and was drawn to this book because it was about WWII and the protagonist was a female. I bought it for a long car trip I was taking.  I was almost a third of the way through the book before the story became compelling.  It was not one of those books where I felt like I just could not put it down.  The actions of the female protagonist as a teenager did not feel authentic.  It got better later in the book, where the author focused more on the protagonist as a 91 year old woman.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on September 3, 2024

title: Historical Fiction with Female Protagonist
content: A story far too many people have forgotten - or not belied.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on October 5, 2024

title: Verified Purchase

title: Broken - but not destroyed

title: Verified Purchase
content: I truly enjoyed how the author showcased an opposing viewpoint of the holocaust, allowing us to see the guilt and pain from a young child that was born into Nazi Germany. An extremely thought provoking novel about guilt and redemption.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on September 10, 2024

title: Excellent story
content: I thought this book to be an interesting read. I enjoy historical fiction, so this novel reads well in that regard. But it stretches the imagination to think that Gretel’s mother, a German trying to hide her German nationality, would go to Paris with her 15 year old daughter after the war. It’s not logical! Perhaps, if they had gone to Switzerland or Sweden or another country that had been neutral during that period it might make sense. But really, you have to suspend belief to think she would have gone to Paris.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on March 25, 2024

title: Verified Purchase
content: Then, I find it hard to believe that Gretel had so much guilt. She was a child/teen when the events happened. She lived in a controlling environment and had been essentially brainwashed from an early age. It was like being in a cult. She knew right from wrong in the context of which she had grown up. This is not to absolve her of all actions, but really the guilt seems overdone considering the lack of control she had over anything. A psychologist could best speak to this, but we do know that a persons brain is often not fully developed until their late to mid- twenties. The heavy guilt about the war did not ring true. Maybe she would have some about her brother, but the rest just seemed a contrived story line. Perhaps if she had been in her late teens this overwhelming guilt trip might make sense.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on September 17, 2024

title: Needs more stars
content: Also, the fact that Gretel did not realize that David was so obviously Jewish given his surname and her background does not ring true. Again, have to suspend belief and go with the storyline
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on August 26, 2024

title: Verified Purchase
content: I have not read The Boy in the Striped Pajamas, so perhaps that would have given greater context to this novel. I found the storyline regarding Heidi and her concern for Henry much more believable and realistic. Although, in some ways I question how likely it was that she and her husband would ended up living in the same building as her daughter that she had given up at birth.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on September 18, 2024

title: Verified Purchase
content: John Boyne's "All The Broken Places" is a gripping novel that won't let go of you even after you have finished it. It's the story of the life a woman who was born the daughter of the Commandant of a Nazi death camp. The story only briefly touches on that time. But of course, her family  history casts a shadow over her entire life.

title: It Good
content: The novel travels through two separate tracks of time. It begins in 2022 where she lives as a 91-year old woman in London. We learn the current situation of her life. The novel then flashes back to protagonist and her mother fleeing from Germany to France after the war. The stories wend separately through the novel, growing closer in time until they finally connect at the last.

title: your family’s prior history can have major effects on your life
content: I just finished All The Broken Places by John Boyne. If a book can be disturbing and riveting all at the same time, it would describe this piece of historical fiction perfectly. This novel is the continuation of the story, The Boy in The Striped Pajamas. However, it primarily centers on Bruno's sister Gretel, and gives details of what happened to her and her family after the war. Like other historical fiction novels, this too alternated between past and present, a clever way to entice the reader to keep turning pages.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on December 10, 2023

title: Verified Purchase
content: I don't want to give too much away in regards to the plot, but what I will say is I had great difficulty liking the main character Gretel, a sign she was well written. At times I had to walk away from the novel because Gretel made me angry and my head spun. She was often self-absorbed and in great denial of the horrors the Nazi Party had created, and then just as quickly would be overcome with guilt and fear of others finding out about her, or her family's past. As the years go by, Gretel matures and appears to accept her family's guilt, while attempting to put the past behind her. But all dark secrets have a way of catching up as she will find in the most unpleasant way.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on April 16, 2024

title: Disturbing and riveting
content: All The Broken Places is very well written, as all John Boyne books tend to be. There are twists and turns in the story that I never anticipated and the ending was a bit of a shock, although I should have seen it coming. This novel was a great way to both continue and end the story of The Boy in The Striped Pajamas.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on April 6, 2024

title: Verified Purchase
content: This is an enjoyable story, fast paced, and well-constructed.  I found interesting, Gretel's journey, the plumbing of her psyche, examining her own involvement and personal guilt concerning her years in Germany as a young adult. Readers will not be disappointed. However, certain elements in the story seemed contrived, and were lacking in credibility. I won't reveal details, due to spoilers, but I sincerely doubt that some events taking place in her life could have happened exactly as told. That is my main criticism, but otherwise I found this a book worth reading
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on July 25, 2024

title: Good book, a few caviats
content: Trigger warning, this book has domestic violence, murder and the Holocaust interwoven throughout the book.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on June 22, 2024

title: Verified Purchase
content: Oh this book! 91 year old Gretel Fernsby has a secret. Well that is an understatement! Her whole life is nothing but secrets. She has lived in the same “flat” for 60+ years. With each passing chapter you learn a little more of her escape from Germany and her attempt to escape her past but sometimes our past is always in the present. And her past does come crashing down on her and she takes care of things as only she could do…at 91, well technically 92 now. You will not forget Gretel Fernsby. This book was unputdownable, I needed to know what the next chapter would reveal. Toward the end of the book there were 2 chapters a mere 38 words that blew my mind. Did not see it coming! Excellent story,
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on September 25, 2024

content: Never a dull moment. I never could guess what might be coming next!

title: Verified Purchase
content: This is the first story of the horrors of Germany I have read about from a young German girl's perspective whose father was a commandant in the German army. Should she have been punished for her father's deeds?  It's up to you to decide.

title: I love a flawed protagonist
content: I love a flawed protagonist. A true hero, someone resplendent in high mortals, after all, is easy to root for.  But a character who does evil, as well as good,  a person who makes the reader squirm a bit as they decide which path they’d take when presented with ethical choices, that’s the kind of figure I prefer at the center of my novels.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on December 29, 2022

title: Verified Purchase
content: Gretel Wilson, or whichever surname she’s using these days, is that kind of character.  Contemporaneously, she’s an adorable 91 year old Londoner who still enjoys strolling through Hyde Park and gossiping with the neighbor across the hallway. But she has a dark past - the daughter of a Nazi commandant who ran a concentration camp - that’s she kept hidden for eight decades.  And that’s about all I want to say about this novel because if you choose to read it, I want it to unfold as perfectly for you as it did for me - one incredible storyline after the other.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on June 17, 2024

title: a sad time in history
content: This isn’t a perfect book.  At times some of the plot twists are a bit too fantastical for my tastes. But it was a novel that I couldn’t put down, that I needed to finish just to find out how Gretel’s story ends, and by my definition, that makes for an awesome read.  As John Boyne writes in his afterward , “it is a novel about guilt, complicity, and grief,” and if you’ve lived a long enough and interesting enough life, you’ve dealt with all of those emotions at some point.  This book will help you examine them even further.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on July 13, 2024

title: read it. one of the best books i've read.
content: From the moment I began to read “All the Broken Pieces”, I was hooked.  The characters were so real, I felt as if I were acquainted with each of them.  Being eighty-one years old myself, I could identify so well with Gretel in her wishes for privacy, her understanding of the motives of her son, her caring for her neighbor.  I have read many books about the jews and how they were treated, but not from the perspective of a german woman who felt such guilt for what her father and her people did during the war.  I highly recommend this book.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on March 3, 2024

title: Verified Purchase
content: I can't say enough about this unusual exploration of the horrors of the Holocaust.  Because it is much more than a condemnation of this tragic period of history.  I can't recall a heroine at the center of a novel who is in her 90's; can you?  This is a page turner.  Complex yet quickly read.  Explores Germany, France, Australia ending in London for main story lines.  It is a sequel to The Boy in the Striped Pajamas, but I cheated and streamed the movie.  This gave me an imaginative view of Gretel's family that I would recommend.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on March 8, 2024

title: Ending is a big surprise
content: This is a must read. More coincidences than Dickens. A great follow up to the Boy in the Striped Pajamas.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on June 20, 2024

title: Verified Purchase
content: This book turned me upside-down. The surprise that left me with my mouth hung open, the gentle prose that carried me back and forth between two eras, the conflicting emotions about the main character... I read at night until my eyes just wouldn't stay open any longer.  I hated having to stop reading because I knew I had to sleep. To say it moved me is too simplistic. Beautiful. Just beautiful.

title: Verified Purchase
content: All The Broken Places is a riveting novel that will keep readers enthralled from start to finish. The author skillfully weaves together a complex plot of internal and external conflicts, complemented by parallel flashbacks that guarantee an unforgettable reading experience. Every page turn brings surprises that heighten the suspense, drawing readers deeper into the story’s mysteries.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on June 28, 2023

title: Amazing, indepth characterization
content: This novel explores what it might be like to survive as a German after WWII. Most of us think there is no way we would be a party to the travesties that occurred. Gretel shows us how surviving had left her scarred, determined, and willing to pay any price for her perceived guilt. This novel is from a point of view I have never read from before. It has taken me to emotional depths, sympathies, and had given me a wider world view.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on March 7, 2024

title: Verified Purchase
content: I read this book in two days and will probably read it again at some point soon. Definitely recommend as an insight to different perspectives on the Holocaust.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on May 24, 2024

title: Hard to Put Down
content: I am deeply floored by this book. John Boyne is such a gifted writer with remarkable insight. This was a story of a family member of a very high ranking SS officer. It is her younger story and her present day story, alternating back and forth chapter by chapter. It dives deeply into the complexity of such a person, the dualities, the guilt, the complicity, as well as the contradictory capacities for compassion as well as cruelty. It’s deeply disturbing, yet a very compelling read. I have read several WWII novels, but I can’t recall one that also takes place in a character’s other phases of life including her geriatric nineties post-pandemic.  I think this is a unique and important story.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on October 1, 2023

title: Verified Purchase
content: I feel I must read The Boy in the Striped Pajamas, which is tied in with the character of this novel.
post_time: Reviewed in the United States on May 16, 2024
